units.title: Cell specialisation and organisation (cells → tissues → organs)
units.summary: Understand cell differentiation, learn key specialised cells, and use the organisation hierarchy confidently.
doneWhen: You can define cell differentiation and give examples.
You can explain adaptations of specialised cells.
You can use cells → tissues → organs → organ systems with examples.

units.title: Cell structure and microscopy
units.summary: Identify cell structures and confidently answer microscopy calculation questions (magnification, real size, image size).
doneWhen: You can label animal/plant/bacterial cells and state key functions.
You can explain prokaryote vs eukaryote differences.
You can do magnification and size conversions without unit errors.

units.title: Homeostasis (intro)
units.summary: Understand what homeostasis is, and the receptor → coordination centre → effector model.
doneWhen: You can define homeostasis.
You can identify receptors, coordination centres, and effectors in examples.

units.title: Paper 1 — Bioenergetics (overview)
units.summary: Big-picture map of photosynthesis and respiration, including required practical concepts.
doneWhen: You can outline photosynthesis + respiration and what affects their rates.

units.title: Paper 1 — Cell biology (overview)
units.summary: Big-picture map of the Cell biology section and how exam questions usually test it.
doneWhen: You can name the main sub-topics in Cell biology and what they mean.

units.title: Paper 1 — Infection and response (overview)
units.summary: Big-picture map of pathogens, transmission, immune response, and drug resistance.
doneWhen: You can name the main sub-topics in Infection and response and what they mean.

units.title: Paper 1 — Organisation (overview)
units.summary: Big-picture map of Organisation: digestive system, circulatory system, gas exchange, plants.
doneWhen: You can name the main sub-topics in Organisation and what they cover.

units.title: Paper 1 — Required practicals (overview)
units.summary: How required practical questions are asked, and the checklist for full marks.
doneWhen: You can write a method with variables + controls.
You can evaluate practical methods (validity, reliability, accuracy, precision).

units.title: Paper 2 — Ecology (overview)
units.summary: Big-picture map of ecosystems, cycles, biodiversity, and human impacts.
doneWhen: You can outline food chains/webs, cycles, and how humans affect ecosystems.

units.title: Paper 2 — Inheritance, variation and evolution (overview)
units.summary: Big-picture map of DNA/genes, inheritance, variation, evolution, and genetic engineering.
doneWhen: You can outline the main inheritance/evolution topics and the key vocabulary.

units.title: Paper 2 — Required practicals (overview)
units.summary: Sampling and ecology practical skills: quadrats, transects, risk, and evaluation.
doneWhen: You can choose a sampling method and justify it.
You can evaluate sampling reliability and bias.

units.title: Transport in cells (diffusion, osmosis, active transport)
units.summary: Understand the 3 key transport processes, apply them to real GCSE scenarios, and avoid common exam traps.
doneWhen: You can correctly define diffusion, osmosis, and active transport.
You can apply them to examples (lungs, gut, root hair cells, dialysis).
You can answer 1–3 mark questions without mixing up the processes.

manifest.name: GOV.UK / NHS Prototyping Kit
manifest.description: Skill-first learning and reference content for the GOV.UK Prototype Kit and NHS variants.

skills.name: Accessibility testing basics
skills.title: Accessibility testing basics
skills.description: Accessibility testing basics involves using built-in browser tools and simple checks to ensure your prototype can be used by people with disabilities. This includes checking keyboard navigation, colour contrast, and screen reader compatibility.

skills.name: Accordions
skills.title: Accordions
skills.description: Accordions allow users to show and hide sections of content on a page. Understanding when to use them and how to implement them accessibly is important for organising long pages.

skills.name: Add delays
skills.title: Add delays
skills.description: Adding delays involves simulating system processing time in your prototype, such as loading spinners or "please wait" pages. This helps test user expectations and design appropriate feedback for slow operations.

skills.name: Add utilities
skills.title: Add utilities
skills.description: Adding utilities involves using helper classes and functions to extend your prototype's functionality. This includes GOV.UK Frontend utility classes for spacing, typography, and layout, as well as creating your own helper functions.

skills.name: Advanced Git
skills.title: Advanced Git
skills.description: Advanced Git involves using branches to work on features separately, merging changes, resolving conflicts, and using Git history to understand or revert changes in your prototype.

skills.name: Archiving old versions
skills.title: Archiving old versions
skills.description: Archiving old versions involves properly storing and documenting past prototype iterations so they can be referenced or restored later. This includes tagging releases, creating branches, and maintaining documentation of what each version contains.

skills.name: Assets folder
skills.title: Assets folder
skills.description: The assets folder is where you store images, custom JavaScript files, and stylesheets for your prototype. Understanding how to organise and reference these files correctly ensures your prototype looks and functions as intended.

skills.name: Autocomplete component
skills.title: Autocomplete component
skills.description: The autocomplete component (also called typeahead or accessible autocomplete) helps users select from a long list of options by filtering as they type. Essential for country selectors, address lookups, or any large list.

skills.name: Backing up prototypes
skills.title: Backing up prototypes
skills.description: Backing up prototypes involves creating copies of your work at key milestones, typically using Git commits, branches, or zip archives. This protects against accidental changes and allows you to return to previous versions.

skills.name: Basic component options
skills.title: Basic component options
skills.description: Basic component options involves passing simple parameters like text, IDs, and labels to GOV.UK Frontend macros to configure how components appear and behave.

skills.name: Basic 'if' statements
skills.title: Basic 'if' statements
skills.description: Basic 'if' statements in Nunjucks allow you to show or hide content based on conditions, such as whether a user has entered certain data or selected a specific option.

skills.name: Basic math in Nunjucks
skills.title: Basic math in Nunjucks
skills.description: Basic math in Nunjucks involves performing simple calculations like addition, subtraction, and multiplication directly in your templates to display computed values.

skills.name: Basic page layouts
skills.title: Basic page layouts
skills.description: Basic page layouts involves using the GOV.UK grid system with rows and columns to structure content on your pages, ensuring consistent spacing and responsive behaviour.

skills.name: Basic page titles
skills.title: Basic page titles
skills.description: Setting basic page titles involves configuring the text that appears in browser tabs and is read by screen readers. This is essential for accessibility and helps users understand where they are.

skills.name: Branding
skills.title: Branding
skills.description: Branding involves applying service-specific headers, logos, and banners to your prototype to match your organisation's identity or test different visual approaches.

skills.name: Building complex macros
skills.title: Building complex macros
skills.description: Building complex macros involves creating sophisticated Nunjucks components with nested logic, multiple parameters, default values, and conditional rendering based on the options passed in.

skills.name: Building wizard patterns
skills.title: Building wizard patterns
skills.description: Building wizard patterns involves creating advanced multi-step interactions with branching logic, progress indicators, and the ability to go back and change answers.

skills.name: Checking accessibility defaults
skills.title: Checking accessibility defaults
skills.description: Checking accessibility defaults involves verifying that components have proper ARIA attributes, labels, and focus states built in, and understanding what accessibility features come out of the box.

skills.name: Cleaning up before sharing
skills.title: Cleaning up before sharing
skills.description: Cleaning up before sharing involves removing unused files, test data, console logs, and commented-out code before sharing your prototype with stakeholders or deploying it for user research.

skills.name: Cleaning up prototypes
skills.title: Cleaning up prototypes
skills.description: Cleaning up prototypes involves refactoring code after user research sessions, removing dead ends and unused code, consolidating learnings, and preparing the prototype for the next iteration or handover.

skills.name: Clearing session data
skills.title: Clearing session data
skills.description: Clearing session data involves resetting the prototype to a clean state, removing all stored user input so you can start a fresh journey without previous answers affecting the experience.

skills.name: Complex data structures
skills.title: Complex data structures
skills.description: Complex data structures involves working with nested objects, arrays of objects, and multi-level data hierarchies that represent real-world service data.

skills.name: Complex 'if/else' logic
skills.title: Complex 'if/else' logic
skills.description: Complex 'if/else' logic involves handling multiple conditions with elif (else if) statements and nested conditionals to manage sophisticated display rules.

skills.name: Conditional components
skills.title: Conditional components
skills.description: Conditional components involves showing or hiding entire components based on user data or logic, such as only displaying certain form fields when relevant conditions are met.

skills.name: Confirmation pages
skills.title: Confirmation pages
skills.description: Confirmation pages are the "end of journey" screens that tell users they've successfully completed a task. They include reference numbers, next steps, and important information.

skills.name: Copying code from the Design System
skills.title: Copying code from the Design System
skills.description: Copying code from the Design System involves finding the right component in the documentation, copying the HTML or Nunjucks example, and adapting it for your prototype.

skills.name: Create custom macros
skills.title: Create custom macros
skills.description: Creating custom macros involves building your own reusable Nunjucks components that accept parameters and output HTML, similar to how GOV.UK Frontend components work.

skills.name: Creating a new page
skills.title: Creating a new page
skills.description: Creating a new page involves adding a new .html file to the app/views folder, setting up the basic template structure, and extending the correct layout to ensure consistency with other pages.

skills.name: Creating data maps
skills.title: Creating data maps
skills.description: Creating data maps involves structuring user input into organised data objects or JSON structures, transforming flat form data into meaningful hierarchies.

skills.name: Custom Nunjucks filters
skills.title: Custom Nunjucks filters
skills.description: Custom Nunjucks filters are JavaScript functions you write to transform data in templates, extending the built-in filters with your own formatting logic.

skills.name: Customizing CSS for patterns
skills.title: Customizing CSS for patterns
skills.description: Customizing CSS for patterns involves writing custom Sass or CSS to modify the appearance of standard components or create new visual styles for your prototype.

skills.name: Customizing the start page
skills.title: Customizing the start page
skills.description: Customizing the start page involves building a standard GOV.UK or NHS service start page with guidance, eligibility information, and a clear call-to-action button.

skills.name: Data in the URL
skills.title: Data in the URL
skills.description: Data in the URL involves understanding how query strings (like ?name=value) can pass information between pages, and how to read these parameters in your prototype.

skills.name: Date manipulation
skills.title: Date manipulation
skills.description: Date manipulation involves calculating dates (like "3 working days from now"), formatting dates for display, and comparing dates in your prototype logic. The date-fns library is commonly used for this.

skills.name: Debugging
skills.title: Debugging
skills.description: Debugging involves systematically finding and fixing problems in your prototype. This includes using browser developer tools, reading terminal error messages, and using console.log to inspect data.

skills.name: Deep linking
skills.title: Deep linking
skills.description: Deep linking involves creating URLs that link directly to specific states or pages within your prototype, including form data or session state. This allows testers to jump directly to a specific point in a journey.

skills.name: Deploying to Heroku
skills.title: Deploying to Heroku
skills.description: Deploying to Heroku involves pushing your prototype code to Heroku's servers so it's accessible online. This includes setting up the app, configuring environment variables, and managing deployments.

skills.name: Design system contribution
skills.title: Design system contribution
skills.description: Design system contribution involves refining prototype patterns to meet the quality standards required for inclusion in the official GOV.UK or NHS design systems.

skills.name: Different data types
skills.title: Different data types
skills.description: Understanding different data types means knowing the difference between strings, numbers, booleans, arrays, and objects. This is essential for handling user input and building logic.

skills.name: Dynamic routing logic
skills.title: Dynamic routing logic
skills.description: Dynamic routing logic involves advanced server-side routing that changes the user's path based on complex combinations of session data, external factors, or calculated states.

skills.name: Email notification preview
skills.title: Email notification preview
skills.description: Email notification preview involves creating pages that show what emails or letters would look like, using data from the user's session. This helps test email content and timing during user research.

skills.name: Environment variables
skills.title: Environment variables
skills.description: Environment variables allow you to configure your prototype differently for local development versus deployment. They're used to store settings like feature flags, API keys, or environment-specific URLs without hardcoding them.

skills.name: Error page handling
skills.title: Error page handling
skills.description: Error page handling involves creating custom 404 (not found) and 500 (server error) pages for your prototype. This helps test how users respond to errors and ensures a consistent experience when things go wrong.

skills.name: Errors in routes
skills.title: Errors in routes
skills.description: Debugging errors in routes involves understanding how the routes.js file works and troubleshooting issues that prevent your prototype from handling form submissions, redirects, and page navigation correctly.

skills.name: Extend layout files
skills.title: Extend layout files
skills.description: Extending layout files involves using Nunjucks template inheritance to modify block structures for specific page needs, creating custom layouts that still inherit from the base template.

skills.name: Filtering data
skills.title: Filtering data
skills.description: Filtering data involves using logic to display specific subsets of information from arrays or objects based on conditions, such as showing only completed tasks or matching search results.

skills.name: Folder structure
skills.title: Folder structure
skills.description: Understanding the folder structure means knowing where to find and place different types of files in the prototype kit. This includes the app folder for views, routes, and assets, as well as configuration files in the root.

skills.name: Form element validation states
skills.title: Form element validation states
skills.description: Form element validation states involves implementing error styling, error messages, and error summaries on form components to show users when they've made mistakes.

skills.name: Form layout design
skills.title: Form layout design
skills.description: Form layout design involves organizing complex forms with fieldsets, legends, hint text, and proper spacing to create accessible, user-friendly form pages.

skills.name: Generating reference numbers
skills.title: Generating reference numbers
skills.description: Generating reference numbers involves creating unique identifiers for submissions or applications in your prototype. These help make confirmation pages feel realistic and can be used to track test scenarios.

skills.name: Git basics
skills.title: Git basics
skills.description: Git basics involves using version control to track changes to your prototype, create commits, and push your code to remote repositories like GitHub. This protects your work and enables collaboration.

skills.name: Hard-coding data
skills.title: Hard-coding data
skills.description: Hard-coding data means placing static content directly into pages for quick testing, rather than pulling it from session data or external sources. This is useful for rapid prototyping.

skills.name: Installing the kit
skills.title: Installing the kit
skills.description: Installing the kit involves downloading the prototype kit, setting up Node.js, and running npm install to get all dependencies. This is the first step before you can start building prototypes.

skills.name: Introduction to Git and GitHub
skills.title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
skills.description: Git is a version control system that tracks changes to your files over time. GitHub is a website that hosts Git repositories online, making it easy to back up your work and collaborate with others. Understanding the basics of both is essential before you start prototyping.

skills.name: Isolating patterns for reuse
skills.title: Isolating patterns for reuse
skills.description: Isolating patterns for reuse involves extracting components from your prototype into standalone, well-documented modules that can be shared across projects or with other teams.

skills.name: Linking pages
skills.title: Linking pages
skills.description: Linking pages involves creating anchor tags and navigation elements that connect different pages in your prototype. This is fundamental to building any user journey.

skills.name: Logic in routes.js
skills.title: Logic in routes.js
skills.description: Logic in routes.js involves moving complex decision-making out of templates and into server-side JavaScript, making code cleaner and enabling more sophisticated processing.

skills.name: Looping through data
skills.title: Looping through data
skills.description: Looping through data involves using Nunjucks 'for' loops to iterate over arrays and objects, displaying lists of items dynamically from data.

skills.name: Managing versions
skills.title: Managing versions
skills.description: Managing versions involves keeping track of different prototype kit versions, updating dependencies safely, and understanding how to roll back if an update causes problems.

skills.name: Mobile responsive testing
skills.title: Mobile responsive testing
skills.description: Mobile responsive testing involves checking your prototype works well on different screen sizes, particularly mobile phones. The GOV.UK Design System is mobile-first, but custom additions need testing.

skills.name: Multi-path journeys
skills.title: Multi-path journeys
skills.description: Multi-path journeys involve designing complex user flows where different users take different routes through the service based on their circumstances, eligibility, or choices.

skills.name: Multi-user testing
skills.title: Multi-user testing
skills.description: Multi-user testing involves setting up your prototype to simulate scenarios where multiple users interact with the same case or application, such as an applicant and a caseworker viewing the same submission.

skills.name: Navigation patterns
skills.title: Navigation patterns
skills.description: Navigation patterns involves implementing sidebars, footers, breadcrumbs, and other navigation elements that help users understand where they are and move through your service.

skills.name: Node.js basics
skills.title: Node.js basics
skills.description: Node.js basics involves understanding that Node.js is the JavaScript runtime that powers the prototype kit. It runs the server that serves your prototype pages and processes your routes.

skills.name: NPM packages
skills.title: NPM packages
skills.description: NPM (Node Package Manager) packages are reusable code libraries that extend the functionality of your prototype. Understanding how to install, update, and manage these dependencies is crucial for maintaining your prototype kit.

skills.name: Nunjucks vs HTML components
skills.title: Nunjucks vs HTML components
skills.description: Understanding Nunjucks vs HTML components means knowing when to use a Nunjucks macro (for dynamic, configurable components) versus plain HTML (for static, one-off content).

skills.name: Nunjucks vs HTML
skills.title: Nunjucks vs HTML
skills.description: Understanding Nunjucks vs HTML means knowing when to use static HTML and when to use Nunjucks templating features like variables, loops, conditionals, and template inheritance to build dynamic pages.

skills.name: Passing variables to macros
skills.title: Passing variables to macros
skills.description: Passing variables to macros involves using session data or other variables to dynamically populate component fields, making forms pre-fill with user data or display personalised content.

skills.name: Password protection
skills.title: Password protection
skills.description: Password protection involves adding simple authentication to your deployed prototype to prevent public access. This is essential when your prototype contains sensitive design work or is hosted publicly.

skills.name: Pattern library management
skills.title: Pattern library management
skills.description: Pattern library management involves organizing, documenting, and maintaining a collection of custom components and patterns within a large prototype or across multiple prototypes.

skills.name: Previewing in local host
skills.title: Previewing in local host
skills.description: Previewing in localhost involves navigating to your local server address (usually localhost:3000) in a browser to view and test your prototype as you develop it.

skills.name: Print stylesheets
skills.title: Print stylesheets
skills.description: Print stylesheets involve creating CSS rules that apply when a user prints a page or saves it as PDF. This ensures important content is visible and unnecessary elements like navigation are hidden in the printed version.

skills.name: Prototype documentation
skills.title: Prototype documentation
skills.description: Prototype documentation involves writing clear README files and inline comments that explain how to run your prototype, what scenarios are available, and any special setup required.

skills.name: Redirecting with logic
skills.title: Redirecting with logic
skills.description: Redirecting with logic involves using routes to send users to different pages based on their form answers, enabling branching journeys and eligibility checks.

skills.name: Restarting the kit
skills.title: Restarting the kit
skills.description: Restarting the kit involves stopping and starting the prototype server, which is sometimes necessary after making changes to routes.js or installing new packages. Most view changes don't require a restart.

skills.name: Running the kit locally
skills.title: Running the kit locally
skills.description: Running the kit locally involves using terminal commands to start the GOV.UK or NHS.UK prototype kit on your own machine. This creates a local web server that lets you view and test your prototype in a browser.

skills.name: Sass compile errors
skills.title: Sass compile errors
skills.description: Sass compile errors occur when the kit's stylesheet preprocessor encounters syntax issues or invalid code. Understanding how to read and fix these errors is essential for customising the appearance of your prototype.

skills.name: Searching/Filtering lists
skills.title: Searching/Filtering lists
skills.description: Searching and filtering lists involves implementing search functionality that filters displayed results based on user input, enabling address lookups, reference searches, and dynamic lists.

skills.name: Setting up VS Code
skills.title: Setting up VS Code
skills.description: Setting up VS Code (Visual Studio Code) involves configuring the editor with helpful extensions and settings for prototyping work. This includes syntax highlighting for Nunjucks, code formatting, and integrated terminal access.

skills.name: Simulate errors
skills.title: Simulate errors
skills.description: Simulating errors involves creating error states, validation messages, and error summary pages in your prototype. This helps test how users respond to problems and ensures your service handles errors gracefully.

skills.name: Skip links and focus management
skills.title: Skip links and focus management
skills.description: Skip links allow keyboard users to bypass repeated navigation and jump to main content. Focus management ensures the keyboard focus moves to the right place after page changes or dynamic updates.

skills.name: Standard data filters
skills.title: Standard data filters
skills.description: Standard data filters are built-in Nunjucks functions like 'default', 'lower', 'upper', and 'trim' that transform data when displaying it in templates.

skills.name: Standard GOV.UK components
skills.title: Standard GOV.UK components
skills.description: Standard GOV.UK components are pre-built, accessible UI elements like buttons, radios, checkboxes, and text inputs that form the foundation of any government service prototype.

skills.name: Standard GOV.UK Page blocks
skills.title: Standard GOV.UK Page blocks
skills.description: Understanding standard GOV.UK page blocks means knowing about the 'content', 'beforeContent', and other named blocks in the page template that you can override to place content in specific areas.

skills.name: Storing user answers
skills.title: Storing user answers
skills.description: Storing user answers involves understanding how form data flows through your prototype. The 'name' attribute on form fields determines the key used in session storage, and this data persists across pages throughout the user's journey.

skills.name: Tables with data
skills.title: Tables with data
skills.description: Tables with data involves using the GOV.UK table component to display structured information, and understanding when tables are appropriate versus other presentation methods.

skills.name: Terminal basics
skills.title: Terminal basics
skills.description: Terminal basics involves understanding how to use the command line interface to navigate folders, run commands, and interact with the prototype kit. This is essential for starting, stopping, and managing your prototype.

skills.name: Terminal shortcuts
skills.title: Terminal shortcuts
skills.description: Terminal shortcuts are keyboard commands that speed up your workflow, such as using the up arrow to repeat previous commands, Ctrl+C to stop processes, and tab completion for file names.

skills.name: Update notifications
skills.title: Update notifications
skills.description: Update notifications appear in the terminal or browser when a new version of the prototype kit or GOV.UK Frontend is available. Understanding these helps you decide when and how to update.

skills.name: Updating the GOV.UK Frontend
skills.title: Updating the GOV.UK Frontend
skills.description: Updating the GOV.UK Frontend involves managing version upgrades of the core design system package, handling breaking changes, and ensuring your prototype continues to work after updates.

skills.name: Use back link correctly
skills.title: Use back link correctly
skills.description: Using the back link correctly involves implementing browser-style back navigation that works reliably, understanding when to use JavaScript history vs explicit URLs.

skills.name: Use macros for items
skills.title: Use macros for items
skills.description: Using macros for items involves implementing GOV.UK Frontend macros with data from loops to generate repeated elements like radio options, checkbox items, or summary list rows dynamically.

skills.name: User research handoff
skills.title: User research handoff
skills.description: User research handoff involves preparing your prototype for user research sessions. This includes creating clear starting points, resetting data between sessions, and documenting which journeys to test.

skills.name: Using block content
skills.title: Using block content
skills.description: Using block content involves advanced use of Nunjucks layout blocks to create custom page structures, such as adding content to the page head, before the main content, or in the footer.

skills.name: Using browser DevTools
skills.title: Using browser DevTools
skills.description: Using browser DevTools involves inspecting HTML, CSS, and JavaScript in the browser to debug layout issues, test changes in real-time, and understand how your prototype renders. Essential for troubleshooting styling and layout problems.

skills.name: Using checkboxes (arrays)
skills.title: Using checkboxes (arrays)
skills.description: Using checkboxes involves understanding that multiple selections are stored as arrays in session data, and knowing how to check if specific values are included.

skills.name: Using data across pages
skills.title: Using data across pages
skills.description: Using data across pages involves passing variables between pages using session storage, hidden fields, or URL parameters, and then rendering dynamic content based on that stored data.

skills.name: Using external JSON files
skills.title: Using external JSON files
skills.description: Using external JSON files involves loading data from separate .json files into your prototype, enabling realistic datasets for testing search, lists, and data-driven features.

skills.name: Using the /index page
skills.title: Using the /index page
skills.description: Using the /index page involves organizing your prototype's landing page to provide clear navigation to different journeys, versions, or test scenarios within your prototype.

skills.name: Validation logic
skills.title: Validation logic
skills.description: Validation logic involves checking whether users have entered required information correctly and displaying appropriate error messages when they haven't.

skills.name: Viewing session data
skills.title: Viewing session data
skills.description: Viewing session data involves using the prototype admin panel (usually at /manage-prototype/clear-data) to inspect what data is currently stored in the session.

skills.name: Views and page templates
skills.title: Views and page templates
skills.description: A view is the visual template that renders what users see in the browser. In the prototype kit, views are Nunjucks files in the app/views folder that combine HTML, design system components, and dynamic data. Views use template inheritance ('extends') to share common layouts across pages.

skills.name: WCAG basics for prototypers
skills.title: WCAG basics for prototypers
skills.description: WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) basics involves understanding the core principles of accessibility: Perceivable, Operable, Understandable, and Robust. Knowing these helps you build prototypes that represent accessible services.

skills.name: What is a macro?
skills.title: What is a macro?
skills.description: A macro is a reusable Nunjucks code block that accepts parameters and outputs HTML. GOV.UK Frontend components are implemented as macros, allowing you to configure them with different options.

skills.name: What is Heroku?
skills.title: What is Heroku?
skills.description: Understanding Heroku means knowing it's a cloud platform that hosts your prototype online, making it accessible to stakeholders and research participants without them needing to run the kit locally.

skills.name: What is POST and GET?
skills.title: What is POST and GET?
skills.description: POST and GET are HTTP methods that determine how data is sent between the browser and server. GET requests fetch pages, while POST requests submit form data. Understanding these is essential for building interactive prototypes.

skills.name: What is Routing?
skills.title: What is Routing?
skills.description: Routing is the mechanism that determines which page to show when a user visits a URL or submits a form. In the prototype kit, routes connect URLs to views and control how users navigate through your prototype.

skills.name: What's in the kit
skills.title: What's in the kit
skills.description: Understanding what's in the kit means knowing the key files, folders, and how the different parts of the GOV.UK or NHS.UK prototype kit work together. This foundational knowledge helps you navigate and modify your prototype effectively.

accessibility-testing-basics.name: Accessibility testing basics
accessibility-testing-basics.title: Accessibility testing basics
accessibility-testing-basics.description: Accessibility testing basics involves using built-in browser tools and simple checks to ensure your prototype can be used by people with disabilities. This includes checking keyboard navigation, colour contrast, and screen reader compatibility.

accordions.name: Accordions
accordions.title: Accordions
accordions.description: Accordions allow users to show and hide sections of content on a page. Understanding when to use them and how to implement them accessibly is important for organising long pages.

add-delays.name: Add delays
add-delays.title: Add delays
add-delays.description: Adding delays involves simulating system processing time in your prototype, such as loading spinners or "please wait" pages. This helps test user expectations and design appropriate feedback for slow operations.

add-utilities.name: Add utilities
add-utilities.title: Add utilities
add-utilities.description: Adding utilities involves using helper classes and functions to extend your prototype's functionality. This includes GOV.UK Frontend utility classes for spacing, typography, and layout, as well as creating your own helper functions.

advanced-git.name: Advanced Git
advanced-git.title: Advanced Git
advanced-git.description: Advanced Git involves using branches to work on features separately, merging changes, resolving conflicts, and using Git history to understand or revert changes in your prototype.

archiving-old-versions.name: Archiving old versions
archiving-old-versions.title: Archiving old versions
archiving-old-versions.description: Archiving old versions involves properly storing and documenting past prototype iterations so they can be referenced or restored later. This includes tagging releases, creating branches, and maintaining documentation of what each version contains.

assets-folder.name: Assets folder
assets-folder.title: Assets folder
assets-folder.description: The assets folder is where you store images, custom JavaScript files, and stylesheets for your prototype. Understanding how to organise and reference these files correctly ensures your prototype looks and functions as intended.

autocomplete-component.name: Autocomplete component
autocomplete-component.title: Autocomplete component
autocomplete-component.description: The autocomplete component (also called typeahead or accessible autocomplete) helps users select from a long list of options by filtering as they type. Essential for country selectors, address lookups, or any large list.

backing-up-prototypes.name: Backing up prototypes
backing-up-prototypes.title: Backing up prototypes
backing-up-prototypes.description: Backing up prototypes involves creating copies of your work at key milestones, typically using Git commits, branches, or zip archives. This protects against accidental changes and allows you to return to previous versions.

basic-component-options.name: Basic component options
basic-component-options.title: Basic component options
basic-component-options.description: Basic component options involves passing simple parameters like text, IDs, and labels to GOV.UK Frontend macros to configure how components appear and behave.

basic-if-statements.name: Basic 'if' statements
basic-if-statements.title: Basic 'if' statements
basic-if-statements.description: Basic 'if' statements in Nunjucks allow you to show or hide content based on conditions, such as whether a user has entered certain data or selected a specific option.

basic-math-in-nunjucks.name: Basic math in Nunjucks
basic-math-in-nunjucks.title: Basic math in Nunjucks
basic-math-in-nunjucks.description: Basic math in Nunjucks involves performing simple calculations like addition, subtraction, and multiplication directly in your templates to display computed values.

basic-page-layouts.name: Basic page layouts
basic-page-layouts.title: Basic page layouts
basic-page-layouts.description: Basic page layouts involves using the GOV.UK grid system with rows and columns to structure content on your pages, ensuring consistent spacing and responsive behaviour.

basic-page-titles.name: Basic page titles
basic-page-titles.title: Basic page titles
basic-page-titles.description: Setting basic page titles involves configuring the text that appears in browser tabs and is read by screen readers. This is essential for accessibility and helps users understand where they are.

branding.name: Branding
branding.title: Branding
branding.description: Branding involves applying service-specific headers, logos, and banners to your prototype to match your organisation's identity or test different visual approaches.

building-complex-macros.name: Building complex macros
building-complex-macros.title: Building complex macros
building-complex-macros.description: Building complex macros involves creating sophisticated Nunjucks components with nested logic, multiple parameters, default values, and conditional rendering based on the options passed in.

building-wizard-patterns.name: Building wizard patterns
building-wizard-patterns.title: Building wizard patterns
building-wizard-patterns.description: Building wizard patterns involves creating advanced multi-step interactions with branching logic, progress indicators, and the ability to go back and change answers.

checking-accessibility-defaults.name: Checking accessibility defaults
checking-accessibility-defaults.title: Checking accessibility defaults
checking-accessibility-defaults.description: Checking accessibility defaults involves verifying that components have proper ARIA attributes, labels, and focus states built in, and understanding what accessibility features come out of the box.

cleaning-up-before-sharing.name: Cleaning up before sharing
cleaning-up-before-sharing.title: Cleaning up before sharing
cleaning-up-before-sharing.description: Cleaning up before sharing involves removing unused files, test data, console logs, and commented-out code before sharing your prototype with stakeholders or deploying it for user research.

cleaning-up-prototypes.name: Cleaning up prototypes
cleaning-up-prototypes.title: Cleaning up prototypes
cleaning-up-prototypes.description: Cleaning up prototypes involves refactoring code after user research sessions, removing dead ends and unused code, consolidating learnings, and preparing the prototype for the next iteration or handover.

clearing-session-data.name: Clearing session data
clearing-session-data.title: Clearing session data
clearing-session-data.description: Clearing session data involves resetting the prototype to a clean state, removing all stored user input so you can start a fresh journey without previous answers affecting the experience.

complex-data-structures.name: Complex data structures
complex-data-structures.title: Complex data structures
complex-data-structures.description: Complex data structures involves working with nested objects, arrays of objects, and multi-level data hierarchies that represent real-world service data.

complex-if-else-logic.name: Complex 'if/else' logic
complex-if-else-logic.title: Complex 'if/else' logic
complex-if-else-logic.description: Complex 'if/else' logic involves handling multiple conditions with elif (else if) statements and nested conditionals to manage sophisticated display rules.

conditional-components.name: Conditional components
conditional-components.title: Conditional components
conditional-components.description: Conditional components involves showing or hiding entire components based on user data or logic, such as only displaying certain form fields when relevant conditions are met.

confirmation-pages.name: Confirmation pages
confirmation-pages.title: Confirmation pages
confirmation-pages.description: Confirmation pages are the "end of journey" screens that tell users they've successfully completed a task. They include reference numbers, next steps, and important information.

copying-code-from-the-design-system.name: Copying code from the Design System
copying-code-from-the-design-system.title: Copying code from the Design System
copying-code-from-the-design-system.description: Copying code from the Design System involves finding the right component in the documentation, copying the HTML or Nunjucks example, and adapting it for your prototype.

create-custom-macros.name: Create custom macros
create-custom-macros.title: Create custom macros
create-custom-macros.description: Creating custom macros involves building your own reusable Nunjucks components that accept parameters and output HTML, similar to how GOV.UK Frontend components work.

creating-a-new-page.name: Creating a new page
creating-a-new-page.title: Creating a new page
creating-a-new-page.description: Creating a new page involves adding a new .html file to the app/views folder, setting up the basic template structure, and extending the correct layout to ensure consistency with other pages.

creating-data-maps.name: Creating data maps
creating-data-maps.title: Creating data maps
creating-data-maps.description: Creating data maps involves structuring user input into organised data objects or JSON structures, transforming flat form data into meaningful hierarchies.

custom-nunjucks-filters.name: Custom Nunjucks filters
custom-nunjucks-filters.title: Custom Nunjucks filters
custom-nunjucks-filters.description: Custom Nunjucks filters are JavaScript functions you write to transform data in templates, extending the built-in filters with your own formatting logic.

customizing-css-for-patterns.name: Customizing CSS for patterns
customizing-css-for-patterns.title: Customizing CSS for patterns
customizing-css-for-patterns.description: Customizing CSS for patterns involves writing custom Sass or CSS to modify the appearance of standard components or create new visual styles for your prototype.

customizing-the-start-page.name: Customizing the start page
customizing-the-start-page.title: Customizing the start page
customizing-the-start-page.description: Customizing the start page involves building a standard GOV.UK or NHS service start page with guidance, eligibility information, and a clear call-to-action button.

data-in-the-url.name: Data in the URL
data-in-the-url.title: Data in the URL
data-in-the-url.description: Data in the URL involves understanding how query strings (like ?name=value) can pass information between pages, and how to read these parameters in your prototype.

date-manipulation.name: Date manipulation
date-manipulation.title: Date manipulation
date-manipulation.description: Date manipulation involves calculating dates (like "3 working days from now"), formatting dates for display, and comparing dates in your prototype logic. The date-fns library is commonly used for this.

debugging.name: Debugging
debugging.title: Debugging
debugging.description: Debugging involves systematically finding and fixing problems in your prototype. This includes using browser developer tools, reading terminal error messages, and using console.log to inspect data.

deep-linking.name: Deep linking
deep-linking.title: Deep linking
deep-linking.description: Deep linking involves creating URLs that link directly to specific states or pages within your prototype, including form data or session state. This allows testers to jump directly to a specific point in a journey.

deploying-to-heroku.name: Deploying to Heroku
deploying-to-heroku.title: Deploying to Heroku
deploying-to-heroku.description: Deploying to Heroku involves pushing your prototype code to Heroku's servers so it's accessible online. This includes setting up the app, configuring environment variables, and managing deployments.

design-system-contribution.name: Design system contribution
design-system-contribution.title: Design system contribution
design-system-contribution.description: Design system contribution involves refining prototype patterns to meet the quality standards required for inclusion in the official GOV.UK or NHS design systems.

different-data-types.name: Different data types
different-data-types.title: Different data types
different-data-types.description: Understanding different data types means knowing the difference between strings, numbers, booleans, arrays, and objects. This is essential for handling user input and building logic.

dynamic-routing-logic.name: Dynamic routing logic
dynamic-routing-logic.title: Dynamic routing logic
dynamic-routing-logic.description: Dynamic routing logic involves advanced server-side routing that changes the user's path based on complex combinations of session data, external factors, or calculated states.

email-notification-preview.name: Email notification preview
email-notification-preview.title: Email notification preview
email-notification-preview.description: Email notification preview involves creating pages that show what emails or letters would look like, using data from the user's session. This helps test email content and timing during user research.

environment-variables.name: Environment variables
environment-variables.title: Environment variables
environment-variables.description: Environment variables allow you to configure your prototype differently for local development versus deployment. They're used to store settings like feature flags, API keys, or environment-specific URLs without hardcoding them.

error-page-handling.name: Error page handling
error-page-handling.title: Error page handling
error-page-handling.description: Error page handling involves creating custom 404 (not found) and 500 (server error) pages for your prototype. This helps test how users respond to errors and ensures a consistent experience when things go wrong.

errors-in-routes.name: Errors in routes
errors-in-routes.title: Errors in routes
errors-in-routes.description: Debugging errors in routes involves understanding how the routes.js file works and troubleshooting issues that prevent your prototype from handling form submissions, redirects, and page navigation correctly.

extend-layout-files.name: Extend layout files
extend-layout-files.title: Extend layout files
extend-layout-files.description: Extending layout files involves using Nunjucks template inheritance to modify block structures for specific page needs, creating custom layouts that still inherit from the base template.

filtering-data.name: Filtering data
filtering-data.title: Filtering data
filtering-data.description: Filtering data involves using logic to display specific subsets of information from arrays or objects based on conditions, such as showing only completed tasks or matching search results.

folder-structure.name: Folder structure
folder-structure.title: Folder structure
folder-structure.description: Understanding the folder structure means knowing where to find and place different types of files in the prototype kit. This includes the app folder for views, routes, and assets, as well as configuration files in the root.

form-element-validation-states.name: Form element validation states
form-element-validation-states.title: Form element validation states
form-element-validation-states.description: Form element validation states involves implementing error styling, error messages, and error summaries on form components to show users when they've made mistakes.

form-layout-design.name: Form layout design
form-layout-design.title: Form layout design
form-layout-design.description: Form layout design involves organizing complex forms with fieldsets, legends, hint text, and proper spacing to create accessible, user-friendly form pages.

generating-reference-numbers.name: Generating reference numbers
generating-reference-numbers.title: Generating reference numbers
generating-reference-numbers.description: Generating reference numbers involves creating unique identifiers for submissions or applications in your prototype. These help make confirmation pages feel realistic and can be used to track test scenarios.

git-basics.name: Git basics
git-basics.title: Git basics
git-basics.description: Git basics involves using version control to track changes to your prototype, create commits, and push your code to remote repositories like GitHub. This protects your work and enables collaboration.

hard-coding-data.name: Hard-coding data
hard-coding-data.title: Hard-coding data
hard-coding-data.description: Hard-coding data means placing static content directly into pages for quick testing, rather than pulling it from session data or external sources. This is useful for rapid prototyping.

installing-the-kit.name: Installing the kit
installing-the-kit.title: Installing the kit
installing-the-kit.description: Installing the kit involves downloading the prototype kit, setting up Node.js, and running npm install to get all dependencies. This is the first step before you can start building prototypes.

introduction-to-git-and-github.name: Introduction to Git and GitHub
introduction-to-git-and-github.title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
introduction-to-git-and-github.description: Git is a version control system that tracks changes to your files over time. GitHub is a website that hosts Git repositories online, making it easy to back up your work and collaborate with others. Understanding the basics of both is essential before you start prototyping.

isolating-patterns-for-reuse.name: Isolating patterns for reuse
isolating-patterns-for-reuse.title: Isolating patterns for reuse
isolating-patterns-for-reuse.description: Isolating patterns for reuse involves extracting components from your prototype into standalone, well-documented modules that can be shared across projects or with other teams.

linking-pages.name: Linking pages
linking-pages.title: Linking pages
linking-pages.description: Linking pages involves creating anchor tags and navigation elements that connect different pages in your prototype. This is fundamental to building any user journey.

logic-in-routes-js.name: Logic in routes.js
logic-in-routes-js.title: Logic in routes.js
logic-in-routes-js.description: Logic in routes.js involves moving complex decision-making out of templates and into server-side JavaScript, making code cleaner and enabling more sophisticated processing.

looping-through-data.name: Looping through data
looping-through-data.title: Looping through data
looping-through-data.description: Looping through data involves using Nunjucks 'for' loops to iterate over arrays and objects, displaying lists of items dynamically from data.

managing-versions.name: Managing versions
managing-versions.title: Managing versions
managing-versions.description: Managing versions involves keeping track of different prototype kit versions, updating dependencies safely, and understanding how to roll back if an update causes problems.

mobile-responsive-testing.name: Mobile responsive testing
mobile-responsive-testing.title: Mobile responsive testing
mobile-responsive-testing.description: Mobile responsive testing involves checking your prototype works well on different screen sizes, particularly mobile phones. The GOV.UK Design System is mobile-first, but custom additions need testing.

multi-path-journeys.name: Multi-path journeys
multi-path-journeys.title: Multi-path journeys
multi-path-journeys.description: Multi-path journeys involve designing complex user flows where different users take different routes through the service based on their circumstances, eligibility, or choices.

multi-user-testing.name: Multi-user testing
multi-user-testing.title: Multi-user testing
multi-user-testing.description: Multi-user testing involves setting up your prototype to simulate scenarios where multiple users interact with the same case or application, such as an applicant and a caseworker viewing the same submission.

navigation-patterns.name: Navigation patterns
navigation-patterns.title: Navigation patterns
navigation-patterns.description: Navigation patterns involves implementing sidebars, footers, breadcrumbs, and other navigation elements that help users understand where they are and move through your service.

nodejs-basics.name: Node.js basics
nodejs-basics.title: Node.js basics
nodejs-basics.description: Node.js basics involves understanding that Node.js is the JavaScript runtime that powers the prototype kit. It runs the server that serves your prototype pages and processes your routes.

npm-packages.name: NPM packages
npm-packages.title: NPM packages
npm-packages.description: NPM (Node Package Manager) packages are reusable code libraries that extend the functionality of your prototype. Understanding how to install, update, and manage these dependencies is crucial for maintaining your prototype kit.

nunjucks-vs-html-components.name: Nunjucks vs HTML components
nunjucks-vs-html-components.title: Nunjucks vs HTML components
nunjucks-vs-html-components.description: Understanding Nunjucks vs HTML components means knowing when to use a Nunjucks macro (for dynamic, configurable components) versus plain HTML (for static, one-off content).

nunjucks-vs-html.name: Nunjucks vs HTML
nunjucks-vs-html.title: Nunjucks vs HTML
nunjucks-vs-html.description: Understanding Nunjucks vs HTML means knowing when to use static HTML and when to use Nunjucks templating features like variables, loops, conditionals, and template inheritance to build dynamic pages.

passing-variables-to-macros.name: Passing variables to macros
passing-variables-to-macros.title: Passing variables to macros
passing-variables-to-macros.description: Passing variables to macros involves using session data or other variables to dynamically populate component fields, making forms pre-fill with user data or display personalised content.

password-protection.name: Password protection
password-protection.title: Password protection
password-protection.description: Password protection involves adding simple authentication to your deployed prototype to prevent public access. This is essential when your prototype contains sensitive design work or is hosted publicly.

pattern-library-management.name: Pattern library management
pattern-library-management.title: Pattern library management
pattern-library-management.description: Pattern library management involves organizing, documenting, and maintaining a collection of custom components and patterns within a large prototype or across multiple prototypes.

previewing-in-local-host.name: Previewing in local host
previewing-in-local-host.title: Previewing in local host
previewing-in-local-host.description: Previewing in localhost involves navigating to your local server address (usually localhost:3000) in a browser to view and test your prototype as you develop it.

print-stylesheets.name: Print stylesheets
print-stylesheets.title: Print stylesheets
print-stylesheets.description: Print stylesheets involve creating CSS rules that apply when a user prints a page or saves it as PDF. This ensures important content is visible and unnecessary elements like navigation are hidden in the printed version.

prototype-documentation.name: Prototype documentation
prototype-documentation.title: Prototype documentation
prototype-documentation.description: Prototype documentation involves writing clear README files and inline comments that explain how to run your prototype, what scenarios are available, and any special setup required.

redirecting-with-logic.name: Redirecting with logic
redirecting-with-logic.title: Redirecting with logic
redirecting-with-logic.description: Redirecting with logic involves using routes to send users to different pages based on their form answers, enabling branching journeys and eligibility checks.

restarting-the-kit.name: Restarting the kit
restarting-the-kit.title: Restarting the kit
restarting-the-kit.description: Restarting the kit involves stopping and starting the prototype server, which is sometimes necessary after making changes to routes.js or installing new packages. Most view changes don't require a restart.

running-the-kit-locally.name: Running the kit locally
running-the-kit-locally.title: Running the kit locally
running-the-kit-locally.description: Running the kit locally involves using terminal commands to start the GOV.UK or NHS.UK prototype kit on your own machine. This creates a local web server that lets you view and test your prototype in a browser.

sass-compile-errors.name: Sass compile errors
sass-compile-errors.title: Sass compile errors
sass-compile-errors.description: Sass compile errors occur when the kit's stylesheet preprocessor encounters syntax issues or invalid code. Understanding how to read and fix these errors is essential for customising the appearance of your prototype.

searching-filtering-lists.name: Searching/Filtering lists
searching-filtering-lists.title: Searching/Filtering lists
searching-filtering-lists.description: Searching and filtering lists involves implementing search functionality that filters displayed results based on user input, enabling address lookups, reference searches, and dynamic lists.

setting-up-vs-code.name: Setting up VS Code
setting-up-vs-code.title: Setting up VS Code
setting-up-vs-code.description: Setting up VS Code (Visual Studio Code) involves configuring the editor with helpful extensions and settings for prototyping work. This includes syntax highlighting for Nunjucks, code formatting, and integrated terminal access.

simulate-errors.name: Simulate errors
simulate-errors.title: Simulate errors
simulate-errors.description: Simulating errors involves creating error states, validation messages, and error summary pages in your prototype. This helps test how users respond to problems and ensures your service handles errors gracefully.

skip-links-and-focus-management.name: Skip links and focus management
skip-links-and-focus-management.title: Skip links and focus management
skip-links-and-focus-management.description: Skip links allow keyboard users to bypass repeated navigation and jump to main content. Focus management ensures the keyboard focus moves to the right place after page changes or dynamic updates.

standard-data-filters.name: Standard data filters
standard-data-filters.title: Standard data filters
standard-data-filters.description: Standard data filters are built-in Nunjucks functions like 'default', 'lower', 'upper', and 'trim' that transform data when displaying it in templates.

standard-govuk-components.name: Standard GOV.UK components
standard-govuk-components.title: Standard GOV.UK components
standard-govuk-components.description: Standard GOV.UK components are pre-built, accessible UI elements like buttons, radios, checkboxes, and text inputs that form the foundation of any government service prototype.

standard-govuk-page-blocks.name: Standard GOV.UK Page blocks
standard-govuk-page-blocks.title: Standard GOV.UK Page blocks
standard-govuk-page-blocks.description: Understanding standard GOV.UK page blocks means knowing about the 'content', 'beforeContent', and other named blocks in the page template that you can override to place content in specific areas.

storing-user-answers.name: Storing user answers
storing-user-answers.title: Storing user answers
storing-user-answers.description: Storing user answers involves understanding how form data flows through your prototype. The 'name' attribute on form fields determines the key used in session storage, and this data persists across pages throughout the user's journey.

tables-with-data.name: Tables with data
tables-with-data.title: Tables with data
tables-with-data.description: Tables with data involves using the GOV.UK table component to display structured information, and understanding when tables are appropriate versus other presentation methods.

terminal-basics.name: Terminal basics
terminal-basics.title: Terminal basics
terminal-basics.description: Terminal basics involves understanding how to use the command line interface to navigate folders, run commands, and interact with the prototype kit. This is essential for starting, stopping, and managing your prototype.

terminal-shortcuts.name: Terminal shortcuts
terminal-shortcuts.title: Terminal shortcuts
terminal-shortcuts.description: Terminal shortcuts are keyboard commands that speed up your workflow, such as using the up arrow to repeat previous commands, Ctrl+C to stop processes, and tab completion for file names.

update-notifications.name: Update notifications
update-notifications.title: Update notifications
update-notifications.description: Update notifications appear in the terminal or browser when a new version of the prototype kit or GOV.UK Frontend is available. Understanding these helps you decide when and how to update.

updating-the-govuk-frontend.name: Updating the GOV.UK Frontend
updating-the-govuk-frontend.title: Updating the GOV.UK Frontend
updating-the-govuk-frontend.description: Updating the GOV.UK Frontend involves managing version upgrades of the core design system package, handling breaking changes, and ensuring your prototype continues to work after updates.

use-back-link-correctly.name: Use back link correctly
use-back-link-correctly.title: Use back link correctly
use-back-link-correctly.description: Using the back link correctly involves implementing browser-style back navigation that works reliably, understanding when to use JavaScript history vs explicit URLs.

use-macros-for-items.name: Use macros for items
use-macros-for-items.title: Use macros for items
use-macros-for-items.description: Using macros for items involves implementing GOV.UK Frontend macros with data from loops to generate repeated elements like radio options, checkbox items, or summary list rows dynamically.

user-research-handoff.name: User research handoff
user-research-handoff.title: User research handoff
user-research-handoff.description: User research handoff involves preparing your prototype for user research sessions. This includes creating clear starting points, resetting data between sessions, and documenting which journeys to test.

using-block-content.name: Using block content
using-block-content.title: Using block content
using-block-content.description: Using block content involves advanced use of Nunjucks layout blocks to create custom page structures, such as adding content to the page head, before the main content, or in the footer.

using-browser-devtools.name: Using browser DevTools
using-browser-devtools.title: Using browser DevTools
using-browser-devtools.description: Using browser DevTools involves inspecting HTML, CSS, and JavaScript in the browser to debug layout issues, test changes in real-time, and understand how your prototype renders. Essential for troubleshooting styling and layout problems.

using-checkboxes-arrays.name: Using checkboxes (arrays)
using-checkboxes-arrays.title: Using checkboxes (arrays)
using-checkboxes-arrays.description: Using checkboxes involves understanding that multiple selections are stored as arrays in session data, and knowing how to check if specific values are included.

using-data-across-pages.name: Using data across pages
using-data-across-pages.title: Using data across pages
using-data-across-pages.description: Using data across pages involves passing variables between pages using session storage, hidden fields, or URL parameters, and then rendering dynamic content based on that stored data.

using-external-json-files.name: Using external JSON files
using-external-json-files.title: Using external JSON files
using-external-json-files.description: Using external JSON files involves loading data from separate .json files into your prototype, enabling realistic datasets for testing search, lists, and data-driven features.

using-the-index-page.name: Using the /index page
using-the-index-page.title: Using the /index page
using-the-index-page.description: Using the /index page involves organizing your prototype's landing page to provide clear navigation to different journeys, versions, or test scenarios within your prototype.

validation-logic.name: Validation logic
validation-logic.title: Validation logic
validation-logic.description: Validation logic involves checking whether users have entered required information correctly and displaying appropriate error messages when they haven't.

viewing-session-data.name: Viewing session data
viewing-session-data.title: Viewing session data
viewing-session-data.description: Viewing session data involves using the prototype admin panel (usually at /manage-prototype/clear-data) to inspect what data is currently stored in the session.

views-and-page-templates.name: Views and page templates
views-and-page-templates.title: Views and page templates
views-and-page-templates.description: A view is the visual template that renders what users see in the browser. In the prototype kit, views are Nunjucks files in the app/views folder that combine HTML, design system components, and dynamic data. Views use template inheritance ('extends') to share common layouts across pages.

wcag-basics-for-prototypers.name: WCAG basics for prototypers
wcag-basics-for-prototypers.title: WCAG basics for prototypers
wcag-basics-for-prototypers.description: WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) basics involves understanding the core principles of accessibility: Perceivable, Operable, Understandable, and Robust. Knowing these helps you build prototypes that represent accessible services.

what-is-a-macro.name: What is a macro?
what-is-a-macro.title: What is a macro?
what-is-a-macro.description: A macro is a reusable Nunjucks code block that accepts parameters and outputs HTML. GOV.UK Frontend components are implemented as macros, allowing you to configure them with different options.

what-is-heroku.name: What is Heroku?
what-is-heroku.title: What is Heroku?
what-is-heroku.description: Understanding Heroku means knowing it's a cloud platform that hosts your prototype online, making it accessible to stakeholders and research participants without them needing to run the kit locally.

what-is-post-and-get.name: What is POST and GET?
what-is-post-and-get.title: What is POST and GET?
what-is-post-and-get.description: POST and GET are HTTP methods that determine how data is sent between the browser and server. GET requests fetch pages, while POST requests submit form data. Understanding these is essential for building interactive prototypes.

what-is-routing.name: What is Routing?
what-is-routing.title: What is Routing?
what-is-routing.description: Routing is the mechanism that determines which page to show when a user visits a URL or submits a form. In the prototype kit, routes connect URLs to views and control how users navigate through your prototype.

whats-in-the-kit.name: What's in the kit
whats-in-the-kit.title: What's in the kit
whats-in-the-kit.description: Understanding what's in the kit means knowing the key files, folders, and how the different parts of the GOV.UK or NHS.UK prototype kit work together. This foundational knowledge helps you navigate and modify your prototype effectively.

units.title: Access local prototype from a mobile device
units.summary: View and test your local prototype on another device on the network.
doneWhen: You can load the prototype from a phone using the machine’s LAN IP.
You understand the basic risks of exposing a local dev server.

units.title: Add modal windows
units.summary: Prototype modal interactions (and decide when you should avoid them).
doneWhen: A modal opens and closes accessibly (focus managed).
You can justify why a modal is the right pattern (or decide not to use it).

units.title: Avoid auto phone-number links
units.summary: Stop browsers auto-linking numbers (especially on mobile).
doneWhen: A number string no longer appears as a phone link on mobile.
You’ve tested the page on at least one mobile browser.

units.title: Check your details (pattern)
units.summary: Implement a realistic “check your answers” page with change links that return to the summary.
doneWhen: Your summary page displays answers captured from previous pages.
Change links let users edit answers and return to the summary page.
Your routing cleanly handles the 'change then return' behaviour.

units.title: Prototype with default data available from the start
units.summary: Seed default answers so the prototype is instantly usable for demos and UR.
doneWhen: The prototype starts with sensible defaults without user input.
You can reset/clear to a blank state when needed.

units.title: Create and import Nunjucks macros
units.summary: Build a reusable macro and import it cleanly across pages.
doneWhen: You’ve created a macro and used it on at least 2 pages.
The macro accepts parameters and renders correctly.

units.title: Create and use default data
units.summary: Seed sensible defaults so prototypes are quicker to test and demo.
doneWhen: The prototype loads with pre-filled example answers.
You can reset/clear back to a blank state.

units.title: Create and use realistic data in a prototype
units.summary: Use realistic example data to make prototypes credible and easier to test.
doneWhen: You have a small set of realistic fixtures (names, dates, addresses, IDs).
The prototype displays that data in at least two places.
You can reset the state to test again quickly.

units.title: Create routes that match multiple URLs
units.summary: Use routing patterns to handle multiple URLs with one handler.
doneWhen: A single route handler can match multiple URLs.
You can extract a parameter from the URL and use it in rendering/logic.

units.title: Embed a YouTube video
units.summary: Embed a responsive video in a unit page with basic accessibility considerations.
doneWhen: A video renders correctly at different screen widths.
You provide captions/transcript guidance.

units.title: Git mental model (for prototyping)
units.summary: Understand commits, branches, remotes, and how GitHub fits in.
doneWhen: You can explain what a commit is, in one sentence.
You can explain what a branch is, in one sentence.
You can push to GitHub and pull changes down.

units.title: Simulate a journey for different types of users
units.summary: Use branching logic and seeded data to represent different user types.
doneWhen: A user can choose a type and the journey adapts accordingly.
At least one page changes content based on user type.
You can reset/clear the user type to test other paths.

units.title: Simulate a realistic search interaction with data
units.summary: Prototype a search flow using structured data and basic filtering.
doneWhen: Users can enter a query and see filtered results.
The results page handles empty/no-match states.
The search state survives at least one navigation step (back/forward or refine).

units.title: Use automated screenshotting
units.summary: Capture screenshots consistently to support review and documentation.
doneWhen: You can generate a repeatable set of screenshots for key pages.
You have a clear naming scheme and a place to store outputs.

units.title: Improve coding productivity
units.summary: Adopt a small set of habits that make prototyping faster and less painful.
doneWhen: You have a consistent folder structure for your prototype(s).
You can debug quickly using logs or DevTools.
You make small commits with meaningful messages.

units.title: Improve coding skills (Terminal, VS Code, workflow)
units.summary: Set up a reliable workflow and learn the minimal terminal/editor skills needed for prototyping.
doneWhen: You can run the kit, restart it, and find errors quickly.
You can use 3+ useful terminal shortcuts/commands for navigation and search.
You have a repeatable workflow for making and sharing changes.

units.title: Install and run a prototype kit project
units.summary: Clone a kit repo, install dependencies, and start the dev server.
doneWhen: You can start the kit with `npm run dev` or `npm start`.
You can load the prototype in your browser.
You know where to look when it fails (terminal output first).

units.title: Use multiple service names
units.summary: Override the header service name on specific pages without changing everything.
doneWhen: Default service name still works everywhere.
At least one page shows an overridden service name.

units.title: Output data to browser dev tools
units.summary: Use the browser console and network tab to debug prototype behaviour.
doneWhen: You can open DevTools and identify a console error.
You can confirm a form submission in the Network tab.

units.title: Output data to the console
units.summary: Add targeted logs to inspect prototype data while you build.
doneWhen: You can print a session value with a clear label.
You can remove/disable the logs before sharing the prototype.

units.title: Publish and collaborate with GitHub Desktop
units.summary: Use GitHub Desktop to commit, push, and open a PR without living in the terminal.
doneWhen: You can commit and push using GitHub Desktop.
You can create a branch and open a PR.
You can pull updates from main.

units.title: Separate different versions
units.summary: Keep multiple prototype versions cleanly separated and easy to navigate.
doneWhen: You can run two versions without editing routes each time.
Old versions are archived and clearly labelled.

units.title: Set up a productive prototyping workstation
units.summary: Optimise your screen, tools, and folder layout so you spend time designing — not wrestling your setup.
doneWhen: You can see VS Code, a terminal, and a browser (with DevTools) without constantly resizing windows.
Your prototype repos live in a consistent folder you can reach quickly from Terminal.
You can run the kit and immediately see build output/errors.

units.title: Set up your prototyping toolchain (Mac)
units.summary: Install the minimum tools (Terminal, VS Code, Node, Git) so you can run a prototype kit locally.
doneWhen: You can run `node -v`, `npm -v`, and `git --version` successfully.
You can open VS Code from the terminal.
You can clone a repo and run `npm install`.

units.title: Share your prototype on your local network
units.summary: Let someone else on the same Wi‑Fi open your in-progress prototype.
doneWhen: You can give someone a URL they can open from another device.
You understand the difference between localhost and LAN IP.

units.title: Nunjucks macros vs HTML for design system components
units.summary: Decide when to use macros vs raw HTML, and keep components maintainable.
doneWhen: You can implement one component using a macro and one using HTML.
You can explain the trade-offs for your team.

units.title: Simulate error handling in a prototype
units.summary: Add realistic validation and error states without overengineering.
doneWhen: You can trigger at least two distinct error states intentionally.
Error messages are clear and appear in the right place(s).

units.title: Support multiple filters files
units.summary: Split filters per version/area and control how they are loaded.
doneWhen: You can load different filters for different versions.
You can explain which filter wins when names clash.

units.title: Terminal minimum for running Prototype Kit projects
units.summary: Learn the small set of terminal commands you need to install dependencies, run the kit, and read errors.
doneWhen: You can navigate into a repo directory using `cd`.
You can install dependencies with `npm install`.
You can start and stop the dev server (`npm run dev`, then `Ctrl + C`).
You can use Tab to autocomplete paths.

units.title: Use branches effectively in Git
units.summary: Create branches for changes, keep them small, and merge safely.
doneWhen: You can create a branch, commit to it, and open a PR without touching main.
You understand when to rebase vs merge (at least at a practical level).

units.title: Use features differently between dev and production
units.summary: Add simple switches so prototypes behave differently when developing vs sharing.
doneWhen: You can toggle at least one behaviour (e.g. debug output) based on environment.
The default shared experience is clean (no debug noise).

units.title: VS Code productivity essentials for prototyping
units.summary: Learn a small set of VS Code habits (shortcuts + command palette) that make everyday edits much faster.
doneWhen: You can use the Command Palette to run common actions without hunting menus.
You can do common edits (move lines, duplicate lines, comment/uncomment) using shortcuts.
You can jump to a specific line number in a file.

units.title: GitHub best practice when prototyping
units.summary: Use GitHub in a way that supports collaboration without slowing you down.
doneWhen: You have a branching + PR workflow that works for the team.
You can tag versions and share links confidently.

units.title: Work with colours in Sass
units.summary: Introduce colour tokens and apply them consistently.
doneWhen: You define at least 2 named colour tokens.
You use tokens instead of hardcoded hex values in your CSS.
